issues.text: whether the High Court had jurisdiction under section 66(4) of the Act to call for a supplemental statement of case

anchor.surface_text: such leave being limited to the question whether the High Court had jurisdiction under section 66(4) of the Act to call for a supplemental statement of case. This is how the appeal has come up for hearing and final disposal before us. We have narrated the facts and events leading up to this appeal in such detail in order that we may have the proper perspective and the background against which the High Court directed the Tribunal to submit a supplementary statement of case on the points mentioned therein. The appeal raises an important question as to the nature, scope and extent of the jurisdiction vested in the High Court under section 66(4) of the Act and we shall now address ourselves to that question.

issues.text: Whether the receipt of the cheques in Bhavnagar amounted to receipt of sale proceeds in Bhavnagar?

anchor.surface_text: Out of the facts stated above the Tribunal raised the following question of law- Whether the receipt of the cheques in Bhavnagar amounted to receipt of sale proceeds in Bhavnagar? The said Reference was heard by the High Court on September 23, 1955, and judgment was delivered the same day whereby the High Court held that it was not possible to answer the question in the absence of materials as to whether the cheques which were received in Bhavnagar were posted by the Government at the request of the appellant and the High Court observed - The question that has been submitted to us by the Tribunal is whether the receipt of the cheques in Bhavnagar amounted to receipt of sale proceeds in Bhavnagar.

issues.text: Was there any evidence on the record to justify the Tribunals finding that the mere receipt by the assessee of cheques of Rs. 2,58,987 and Rs. 13,08,980 in Bhavnagar amounted to receipt of the above amounts in Bhavnagar even though the said cheques had actually been cashed in British India and the proceeds thereof were credited to the assessees accounts with certain Banks in British India ?

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the respondent submitted that the following questions of law arose out of the order of the Tribunal- Was there any evidence on the record to justify the Tribunals finding that the mere receipt by the assessee of cheques of Rs. 2,58,987 and Rs. 13,08,980 in Bhavnagar amounted to receipt of the above amounts in Bhavnagar even though the said cheques had actually been cashed in British India and the proceeds thereof were credited to the assessees accounts with certain Banks in British India ? Whether in the circumstances of this case, the income, profits and gains in respect of the sales amounting,to Rs. 15,67,967 made to the Government of India and other customers were received in British India within the meaning of section 4(1)(a) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

issues.text: Whether in the circumstances of this case, the income, profits and gains in respect of the sales amounting to Rs. 15,67,967 made to the Government of India and other customers were received in British India within the meaning of section 4(1)(a) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the circumstances of this case, the income, profits and gains in respect of the sales amounting to Rs. 15,67,967 made to the Government of India and other customers were received in British India within the meaning of section 4(1)(a) of the Indian Income-tax Act. A similar statement of facts which were admitted and or found by the Tribunal was also made in regard to the assessment year 1944-45 and similar questions of law were asked to be referred as in the case of the assessment year 1943-44 except in regard to the change in the figures necessitated by the differences in the amounts received.

issues.text: whether if the cheques were received by post, the post office was constituted the agent of the assessee or not

anchor.surface_text: The question that has been submitted to us by the Tribunal is whether the receipt of the cheques in Bhavnagar amounted to receipt of sale proceeds in Bhavnagar. This question over-looks the important aspect which was dealt with both by us in Kirloskars case and also by the Supreme Court. Assuming that the cheques were received in Bhavnagar, the question still, remains as to whether if the cheques were received by post, the post office was constituted the agent of the asseessee or not.

arguments.claim: Payments by cheques received at Bhavnagar were received in British India at the place where the cheques were cashed and honoured.

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue had not disputed the fact that the cheques had been actually received at Bhavnagarbut had contended that payments by cheques, though such cheques were received at Bhavnagar, were received in British India at the time and the place where the cheques were ultimately cashed and honoured by the banks on which the cheques were drawn and that until such encashment of the cheques, the monies could not be said to have been received by the appellant.

arguments.claim: Cheques are not legal tender and receipt of cheques at Bhavnagar is not receipt of money; receipt occurs on encashment by drawee banks.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner by his two separate orders confirmed the orders of the Income-tax officer and held that the cheques were not legal tender and were not monies or monies worth as such and that the receipt of cheques at Bhavnagar was not receipt of money.

arguments.claim: Cheques from Government were received at Bhavnagar and money was received there; presumption that letters containing cheques addressed to assessee at Bhavnagar.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal stated inter- alia as follows- There is noevidence that the cheques from Government were received in Bhavnagar. It is not the Departments case that the assessee company has a registered office elsewhere. The presumption is that the letters containing the cheques were addressed to the assessee company at Bhawagar

arguments.claim: No evidence produced that cheques received at Bhavnagar or as unconditional discharge; collected by bankers in British India.

anchor.surface_text: No evidence was produced by the assessee at any stage even before the Appellate Tribunal, that the cheques were received at Bhavnagar, no was any evidence produced to show that these cheques were received as unconditional discharge of debtors liability. These cheques were collected by the Companys bankers in British India.

arguments.claim: Tribunal held receipt at Bhavnagar without enquiring if unconditional discharge of liability.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, relied upon the Bombay High Court decision in Kirloskar Brothers case and held that the amount was received in Bhavnagar. As regards items of Rs. 13,08,980 and Rs. 5,53,447 received in the accounting years relevant to the assessments for 1943-44 and 1944-45 respectively,

arguments.claim: Mere receipt of cheques by post in Bhavnagar does not constitute receipt of sale proceeds unless not at request of assessee; post office may be agent.

anchor.surface_text: The question that has been submitted to us by the Tribunal is whether the receipt of the cheques in Bhavnagar amounted to receipt of sale proceeds in Bhavnagar. This question over-looks the important aspect which was dealt with both by us in Kirloskars case and also by the Supreme Court.

arguments.qualifiers: assuming that the cheques were received in Bhavnagar

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Tribunal may number companytain sufficient material to enable the High Court to determine the question raised thereby and in that case the High Court

arguments.court_reasoning: New aspect not canvassed before Tribunal; does not arise out of Tribunal's order.

arguments.claim: High Court has right under s.66(4) independently of parties' conduct to direct Tribunal to state further facts for advisory jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: But we cannot shut out the necessary inquiry which even from our own point of view is necessary to be made in order that we should satisfactorily answer the question raised in the Reference. It must not be forgotten that under sec. 66(4) of the Income-tax Act we have a right independently

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ditions to those statements or alterations therein as may be directed by the Court. Even though the terms of s. 66 4  are wide enough to companyprise

arguments.court_reasoning: s.66(4) limited to enabling determination of referred question; cannot introduce new questions or enquiries not arising from Tribunal order.

arguments.claim: Only questions of law arising out of Tribunal's order can be referred under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: It is clear on a plain reading of the terms of s. 66(1) that the only question of law which the assesssee or the Commissioner can require the Tribunal to refer to the High Court is any question of law arising out of the order of the Tribunal

arguments.claim: s.66(4) allows High Court to refer back only for additions/alterations to determine the referred question, not new questions or facts.

anchor.surface_text: If the High Court is not satisfied that the statements in a case referred under this section are sufficient to enable it to determine the question raised thereby, the Court may refer the case back to the Appellate Tribunal to make such additions thereto or alterations therein as the Court may direct

arguments.claim: High Court's jurisdiction under s.66 is consultative/advisory, limited to facts admitted/found by Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 66 is a consultative or advisory jurisdiction. In order to satisfactorily discharge that advisory jurisdiction the High Court must have before it all the facts which are admitted and or found by the Tribunal properly set out in the Statements

arguments.claim: Cannot give party second chance for new contention or evidence under s.66(4).

anchor.surface_text: it would be contrary to all principle to give it another chance to establish by fresh and different evidence a quite different contention which, if it was desired to rely upon it, ought to have been advanced in the first instance.

arguments.claim: High Court cannot allow new points not raised before Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We intimated to Mr. Meyer as soon as he formulated his points that he could not be allowed to take the first of them, since it did not appear to have been taken on behalf of the Department at any stage of the proceedings and certainly not before the Tribunal.

arguments.claim: Statement of case limited to materials before Tribunal; cannot buttress with new evidence.

anchor.surface_text: A statement of the case is not intended for the purpose of buttressing up the order of the Appellate Tribunal or further fortifying it by requisitioning to its aid materials and evidence which were not before the Tribunal but which it discovers by investigation after the order was passed

arguments.claim: High Court has no power under s.66 to remand for new determinations left undetermined.

anchor.surface_text: We do not find any power in this Court under the provisions of section 66 of the Income-tax Act to remand a matter back to the Tribunal for determining what might have been left undetermined by them, because they took a particular view of the law.

arguments.claim: Cannot raise new points requiring further evidence for first time in High Court.
Visweshwar Singh allows rehearing for relevant findings on point at issue, but not new enquiry.
arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished as not permitting fresh line of enquiry never canvassed earlier.

arguments.claim: Sunder Singh supports remanding under s.66(4) for missing material facts.
arguments.court_reasoning: No discussion of scope of s.66(4); similar to Visweshwar, not for new issues.

arguments.claim: Post office agent issue was not canvassed before Tribunal or in ref applications; does not arise out of order.

anchor.surface_text: this aspect of the case, viz., whether any portion of these cheques were received by post and if so whether there was any request by the appellant express or implied that the amounts of those cheques should be remitted to Bhavnagar by post, had certainly not been canvassed before any of the income-tax authorities

arguments.claim: To extent cheques not received by post but by hand, receipt in Bhavnagar for tax purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Johi concedes that to the extent that the cheques were not received by post but by hand, the receipt will be for the purpose of tax in Bhavnagar.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in directing supplementary statement; no jurisdiction as new question.

holdings.text: The High Court had no jurisdiction under section 66(4) of the Act to direct the Tribunal to submit a supplementary statement of case on new points not arising out of the Tribunal's order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.66(4) limited to additions/alterations for determining referred question; new enquiry on post office agency not canvassed before Tribunal, does not arise out of order.

holdings.text: Only questions of law arising out of the Tribunal's order can be referred to the High Court under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: It is clear on a plain reading of the terms of s. 66(1) that the only question of law which the assessesee or the Commissioner can require the Tribunal to refer to the High Court is any question of law arising out of the order of the Tribunal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain reading of s.66(1); reference based on facts admitted/found by Tribunal.

holdings.text: Under s.66(4), High Court can refer back only for additions or alterations sufficient to determine the referred question, not to introduce new questions or facts.

anchor.surface_text: If the High Court is not satisfied that the statements in a case referred under this section are sufficient to enable it to determine the question raised thereby, the Court may refer the case back to the Appellate Tribunal to make such additions thereto or alterations therein as the Court may direct

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation harmonized with s.66(1)/(2); cannot enlarge scope of reference.

holdings.text: The High Court's jurisdiction under s.66 is consultative or advisory, confined to facts admitted or found by the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 66 is a consultative or advisory jurisdiction. In order to satisfactorily discharge that advisory jurisdiction the High Court must have before it all the facts which are admitted and or found by the Tribunal properly set out in the Statements

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation to ensure advice only on agitated matters; supported by precedents.

holdings.text: It is contrary to principle to allow a party a second chance under s.66(4) to establish a new contention with fresh evidence not advanced earlier.

anchor.surface_text: it would be contrary to all principle to give it another chance to establish by fresh and different evidence a quite different contention which, if it was desired to rely upon it, ought to have been advanced in the first instance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy against new cases via remand; cites Craddock case.

holdings.text: High Court cannot permit new points not raised before the Tribunal in a reference under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: We intimated to Mr. Meyer as soon as he formulated his points that he could not be allowed to take the first of them, since it did not appear to have been taken on behalf of the Department at any stage of the proceedings and certainly not before the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Practice limits to points canvassed before Tribunal; cites State Bank of India case.

holdings.text: Statement of case cannot include new evidence discovered after Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: A statement of the case is not intended for the purpose of buttressing up the order of the Appellate Tribunal or further fortifying it by requisitioning to its aid materials and evidence which were not before the Tribunal but which it discovers by investigation after the order was passed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Industrial Development case; limited to record before Tribunal.

holdings.text: High Court has no power under s.66 to remand for new determinations left undetermined by Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We do not find any power in this Court under the provisions of section 66 of the Income-tax Act to remand a matter back to the Tribunal for determining what might have been left undetermined by them, because they took a particular view of the law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Vadilal Ichhachand; jurisdiction only to answer referred question of law.
